questions.text: Which of the following is the second most common malignancy in childhood?
questions.solution:
The second most common malignancy in childhood is a brain tumor.

The most common malignancy in childhood is Leukemias.

Brain tumors in childhood:

  • Most common solid tumor in children- Brain tumor
  • Most common site of a brain tumor in children- Infratentorium
  • Most common brain tumor in childhood- Pilocytic astrocytoma

 

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

questions.text: The MRI scan of an 11-year-old girl revealed a brain tumor. In which of the following conditions would you do a lumbar puncture for cytological analysis?
questions.solution:
Germ-cell tumor is an indication for lumbar puncture for cytological analysis of CSF.

Usually, lumbar punctures are contraindicated in intracranial space-occupying lesions with high intracranial pressure as it can lead to brain herniation and death. They are thus delayed until surgery or shunt placement. However, in tumors with a risk of leptomeningeal metastases, lumbar puncture is indicated for cytology.

Tumors where LP is indicated  Tumors where LP is contraindicated 

Medulloblastoma or primitive neuroectodermal tumors

Infratentorial tumors

Ependymoma

Supratentorial tumors with midline shift

Germ cell tumors

Tumors with hydrocephalus secondary to CSF obstruction

questions.text: A mother brought her 10-month-old baby to the hospital with sudden onset vomiting. She has also been noticing an alarming increase in the head size of the baby. On examination, significant macrocephaly is seen. MRI reveals a supratentorial tumor. Which of the following tumors is the most likely cause of this child's presentation?
questions.solution:
Choroid plexus carcinoma is a pediatric supratentorial tumor presenting with macrocephaly and focal neurologic deficits.

Choroid plexus tumors are the most common CNS tumors in children aged less than 1 year. These tumors are intraventricular epithelial neoplasms arising from the choroid plexus. 

Children present with signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), whereas infants may present with macrocephaly and focal neurologic deficits.

Medulloblastoma, pilocytic astrocytoma, and ependymoma, are all predominantly infratentorial tumors.

The age-related differences in the primary location of the tumor are given below:

Age Predominant Site Examples
< 1 year Supratentorial Choroid plexus tumor and teratoma
1 - 10 years Infratentorial Juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma and medulloblastoma
> 10 years Supratentorial Diffuse astrocytoma

questions.text: Sanam, a 7-year-old kid is suspected to have an ependymoma. Which of the following features on histopathology would favor this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Perivascular rosettes will be seen on histopathological examination of ependymoma. Other features include ependymal rosettes and monomorphic nuclear morphology.

Ependymomas are tumors derived from the ependymal lining of the ventricular system occurring predominantly in childhood. They are usually non-invasive, extending into the ventricular lumen and/or displacing normal structures, sometimes leading to significant obstructive hydrocephalus.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A young child was evaluated for increased ICP. A brain tumor was found on an MRI scan. It was resected and sent for histopathological examination. The slide is shown below. This tumor is found most commonly in the __________.

questions.text: A concerned mother brought her daughter to the clinic for evaluation of symptoms that have worsened in the last few weeks. The daughter frequently wakes up at night with severe headaches and vomiting. She has also been having some difficulty walking. On examination, ataxia and multiple cranial nerve palsies are noted.  Imaging is suggestive of a brainstem tumor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The MRI given shows a diffuse, infiltrating pontine lesion. Multiple cranial nerve dysfunctions, cerebellar signs, motor weakness, and features of raised intracranial pressure (ICP) are all strongly suggestive of a pontine glioma.

These are not amenable for surgical resection. The standard approach is radiation therapy. The prognosis is very poor.

questions.text: On your neurology rotation, you come across Ashu, a 5-year-old child who presented with a 6-month history of ataxia, headaches, and vomiting. He was admitted to the ward for further evaluation. MRI scan showed a brain tumor with a combination of solid and cystic components. Biopsy findings of the tumor are shown in the image.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows condensed masses of glial filaments occurring in compact areas suggestive of Rosenthal fibers. The clinical features, MRI findings, and histopathology point towards a diagnosis of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a low-grade astrocytoma tumor. It is the most common type of astrocytoma in children. These are classically found in the cerebellum (infratentorial) and the optic pathway regions.

There is usually a 3-6 month history of limb ataxia, secondary headaches, and vomiting. Mural nodule, a contrast medium enhancing nodule within the wall of a cystic mass is seen on MRI. 

The tumor has a low metastatic potential and is rarely invasive.

questions.text: What is the WHO grading for Pilomyxoid astrocytoma?
questions.solution:
Pilomyxiod astrocytoma falls under WHO Grade II.

Pilomyxoid astrocytoma:

Occurs most commonly in the hypothalamic/optic chiasmic region and carries a high risk of local as well as cerebrospinal spread. This astrocytoma affects young children and infants. It is classified as a WHO grade II tumor.

questions.text: You are a pathology resident who is looking at a slide, showing small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes as shown below. The history you received from the pediatric surgery resident was that the specimen was resected from a 5-year-old child with ataxia. The tumor was present in the midline vermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and slide are suggestive of Medulloblastoma. 

Medulloblastoma is an embryonal CNS tumor, occurring predominantly in the cerebellar vermis that causes ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. It may cause obstructive hydrocephalus and often metastasizes extraneurally.

Histopathology shows a tumor composed of small, round, blue cells and is characterized by Homer–Wright rosettes and an immunopositivity for synaptophysin. 

Standard treatment for medulloblastomas is surgical resection, with adjuvant craniospinal radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy.
Prognosis is strongly influenced by surgical resection, the presence of CSF metastases at the time of diagnosis, and the expression of the c-erbB-2 (HER2/neu) oncogene.

Note: Small, round, blue-cell tumors are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic appearance under the microscope. It consists of sheets of small round cells that stain blue on routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. Examples are:

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

A new study shows that children with medulloblastoma who were treated with radiotherapy had better intellectual outcomes when the radiation was delivered as proton beam therapy compared to traditional photon radiotherapy.

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency department by his teacher when he started having abnormal jerking movements during math class. The parents give a history of the child having similar episodes in the past. On the way to the CT room, the child had an episode of seizure and was stabilized with lorazepam. The imaging done is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Calcified cortical mass with a seizure is suggestive of oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendrogliomas are uncommon tumors of childhood. These infiltrating tumors occur predominantly in the cerebral cortex and originate in white matter. Treatment involves surgical resection followed by involved field radiation therapy.

The image below shows histology of oligodendroglioma showing characteristic fried egg appearance and chicken wire capillaries.

 

Craniopharyngioma is associated with suprasellar calcification. Also, the child may often present with a history of endocrinological and visual complaints.

questions.text: An erythropoietin-secreting brain tumor is detected in a child. His father passed away one year back from end-stage renal cell carcinoma. Family history is significant for VHL mutation. On examination, a fiery red retina is seen. Which of the following is the most likely tumor present in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition. The major neurological features of VHL include cerebellar hemangioblastomas and retinal angiomas.

Cerebellar hemangioblastomas are erythropoietin-secreting tumors, which can lead to polycythemia. It typically appears as a cystic cerebellar lesion with a vascular mural nodule on CT or MRI scan.

Retinal angiomas are small masses of thin-walled capillaries, usually located in the peripheral retina that is fed by large and tortuous arterioles and venules appearing as a fiery red vascular mass. It can lead to retinal detachment and visual loss.

Associations of VHL syndrome include:

  • Cystic lesions of kidneys, pancreas, liver, and epididymis
  • Renal cell carcinoma (most common cause of death)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
  • Retinal angioma

World Brain Tumour Day is observed annually on June 8 to raise awareness among the public regarding brain tumours, and the importance of early diagnosis and treatment. The campaign also stresses the importance of more research on brain tumours to enhance the treatment methods.

  • Hepatoma
  • Cerebellar hemangioma
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Pheochromocytomas
  • Virilizing ovarian tumors
  • Wilms’ tumor

questions.text: Akhil, a 15-year-old boy with sun-setting eyes, has a tumor in the pineal region as seen in the MRI. Parinaud syndrome is suspected. Which of the following findings will not be seen in this boy?

choices.text: Convergence retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze

questions.solution:
Parinaud’s syndrome refers to supranuclear vertical gaze disorder.

Parinaud’s syndrome/dorsal midbrain syndrome is caused by damage to the posterior commissure. Classically, signs of hydrocephalus are seen due to aqueductal stenosis.

Causes:

  • Pineal region or midbrain tumors (Most common cause)
  • Neurocysticercosis
  • Stroke
  • Multiple sclerosis

Features include the following:

  • Loss of up-gaze (downward gaze is usually preserved)
  • Convergence–retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze
  • Downward ocular deviation- Setting-sun sign
  • Lid retraction- Collier's sign
  • Pseudo-Argyll–Robertson pupil- Accommodative paresis ensues and pupils become mid-dilated and show light-near dissociation
  • Bilateral papilledema
  • Skew deviation
  • Pseudoabducens palsy

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the casualty after a minor accident that occurred when he failed to see a bike coming from sideways. His mother says he is a clumsy child, who sometimes knocks things over accidentally even at home. Visual field examination findings are given below. On imaging, an intracranial mass is seen. The resected specimen shows cholesterol-rich machinery-oil-like fluid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Patients with adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma present with bitemporal hemianopia (image), and the cystic component of this tumor contains a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid that is comparable to "machine oil."

Craniopharyngiomas develop from remnants of the Rathke pouch. Adamantinomatous variant of craniopharyngioma predominates in childhood.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur in the suprasellar region. Patients usually present with headache and visual field abnormalities. These children also have endocrinological abnormalities such as growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to hypopituitarism (GH deficiency).

These tumors are minimally invasive, adhere to the adjacent brain parenchyma, and engulf normal brain structures. CT may show calcifications associated with the solid and cystic components.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common extracranial solid tumor in the pediatric age group?
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children and the most commonly diagnosed malignancy in infants. It is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral nervous system.

The signs and symptoms depend on the location of the tumor and the extent of the disease. Neuroblastomas originating from the superior cervical ganglion can present with Horner syndrome.

Metastatic disease can cause a variety of signs and symptoms, including the following

  • Fever
  • Irritability
  • Failure to thrive
  • Bone pain
  • Cytopenia
  • Bluish subcutaneous nodules
  • Orbital proptosis, and periorbital ecchymoses

Rapid dancing eye movements (opsoclonus), rhythmic jerking of limbs/trunk (myoclonus), and ataxia are characteristic of the opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMA). It is a paraneoplastic syndrome of autoimmune origin with a strong association with neuroblastomas.

Some neuroblastomas may undergo spontaneous regression, whereas some may be unresponsive to therapy and run a very aggressive course.

  Neuroblastoma Wilm's tumor (nephroblastoma)
Age group <2 years of age Peaks at 3-4 years of age
Calcifications Very common (90%) Uncommon (10-15%)
Margins

Poorly marginated

Well circumscribed
Vascular invasion

Encases vascular structures but does not invade them

Extends into the IVC and renal vein
Relation with surrounding structures

Elevates the aorta away from the vertebral column

Commonly crosses the midline, especially behind the aorta

Displaces adjacent structures without insinuating between them

Forms the claw sign with the kidney

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with rapid dancing eye movements, rhythmic jerking of limbs and poor coordination. You suspect a paraneoplastic syndrome. Which of the following conditions should you look for in this child?
questions.solution:
Rapid dancing eye movements (opsoclonus), rhythmic jerking of limbs/trunk (myoclonus) and ataxia is characteristic of opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMA). It is a paraneoplastic syndrome of autoimmune origin with a strong association with neuroblastoma.

All children with OMA should undergo investigations for neuroblastoma such as ultrasound followed by CT or MRI of chest and abdomen, bone scans and marrow biopsies. The definitive diagnosis of neuroblastoma is through biopsy which shows small round blue cells.

Other small round blue cell tumours are medulloblastoma, retinoblastoma, Ewing’s sarcoma and rhabdomyosarcoma.

questions.text: In the ophthalmology OPD, you see a 3-year-old child with the following finding. There is no history of trauma. There is no significant family history. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This image shows periorbital ecchymoses and proptosis suggestive of metastases of neuroblastoma (a sign of orbital bone involvement).

Neuroblastomas may develop at any site in the sympathetic nervous system. Metastatic spread is common in children who are diagnosed after 1 year of age. It occurs via local invasion, hematogenous, or lymphatic routes.

Metastatic disease can cause a variety of signs and symptoms, including the following:

    • Fever
    • Irritability
    • Failure to thrive
    • Bone pain
    • Cytopenia
    • Bluish subcutaneous nodules
    • Orbital proptosis, and periorbital ecchymoses

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant is diagnosed with neuroblastoma. Which of the following factors is associated with a good prognosis?
questions.solution:
Hyperdiploidy is associated with a good prognosis in neuroblastoma if the child is younger than 1 year of age at diagnosis.

Bad prognosis in neuroblastoma is seen in cases of:

  • Amplification of N-MYC 
  • Loss of Heterozygosiy of 1p, 11 q ,14q
  • Gain of 17q
  • TrkB expression

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with a 2-month history of an enlarging scalp lesion. There is no history of trauma to the head or scalp. The child is otherwise healthy and investigations are normal. X-ray of the head is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the x-ray image showing a punched-out lytic lesion is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

LCH is a rare histiocytic disorder characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions that can infiltrate nearly every organ, most notably the skin (of the scalp), lungs, thymus, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system.

LCH is so named because of its resemblance to the Langerhan’s cells, which are specialized dendritic cells found in the skin and mucosa.

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhanâ€™s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought with 4 small, purplish, rubbery lesions on his back and arms. On examination, you note inguinal freckling and nodules on the iris as shown below. Which chromosome is involved in the syndrome described in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1. The NF1 gene on chromosome 17q11 is involved. It is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome. 

It is diagnosed when at least 2 of the following 7 criteria are met: 

  1. 6 or more cafe-au-lait macules 
    1. >5mm prepuberty 
    2. >15mm post-puberty
  2. Skin-fold freckling- axillary and inguinal 
  3. 2 or more iris lisch nodules (image) 
  4. 2 or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma (purplish, rubbery lesions)
  5. Osseous lesions
    1. Osseous dysplasia 
    2. Cortical thinning of long bones without a pseudoarthrosis 
  6. Low-grade astrocytomas like optic gliomas 
  7. 1st degree relative with diagnosed NF-1

questions.text: Vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and spinal cord ependymomas are the CNS manifestations of __________.
questions.solution:
Vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and spinal cord ependymomas are the CNS manifestations of neurofibromatosis type 2

It is an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to a mutation in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22q12.

von Hippel–Lindau syndrome is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to a mutation in the VHL gene on chromosome 3p25-26. The CNS manifestation is usually a hemangioblastoma. 

Turcot syndrome is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to a mutation in the APC gene on chromosome 5q21. The CNS manifestation is a medulloblastoma.

questions.text: What is the most common intraocular tumor diagnosed in the pediatric age group?
questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular tumor of the pediatric age group. It is an embryonal malignancy of the retina.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: James was brought by his mother for evaluation of a squint she noticed. On examination, the given finding was observed. Investigations revealed retinoblastoma with a germline RB1 gene mutation. The secondary malignancy most likely to develop in him is:
questions.solution:
Children with germline RB1 mutations are at significant risk for the development of secondary malignancies, especially

  • Osteosarcoma (Most common)
  • Soft tissue sarcomas
  • Malignant melanoma

The risk of secondary malignancies is further increased by the use of radiation therapy. 

A pineoblastoma occurring in a child with bilateral hereditary retinoblastoma is called 'trilateral retinoblastoma'.

The image shows leukocoria, a white pupillary reflex. It may be seen in the following conditions: 

  • Congenital cataract
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Retinopathy of prematurity (retrolental fibroplasia)
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous
  • Coats disease
  • Toxocara endophthalmitis

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with an abdominal mass. On examination, the mass is firm, smooth, non-tender, and does not cross the mid-line. The boy is also found to have moderate hypertension. Urinalysis reveals microscopic haematuria. Wilms tumor is suspected. This condition can be associated with all of the following except  ___________.
questions.solution:
Polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilm's tumor.

Wilms tumor (WT), also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. 

Polycystic kidney disease can also present with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and hematuria. However, there will be multiple irregular cysts on ultrasound and is not associated with Wilms tumor.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis

  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: You are assisting on a left partial nephrectomy in a child with Wilms tumor. Intraoperatively, a small mass is noted on the right kidney as well. Frozen section reveals it to be a Wilms tumor. What is the stage of Wilm's tumor in this child?
questions.solution:
Wilms tumor with involvement of both kidneys is stage 5.

Children’s Oncology Group (COG) Staging System

Stage I

Tumor confined to the kidney and completely resected with negative lymph nodes.

Stage II

Tumor extends beyond the kidney but is completely resected with negative margins and lymph nodes.

Stage III

Residual tumor present following surgery confined to the abdomen, including gross or microscopic tumor.

Stage IV

Hematogenous metastases (lung, liver, bone, brain, etc.)

or lymph node metastases outside the abdominopelvic region

Stage V

Metastasis to opposite kidney (bilateral renal involvement)

questions.text: While posted in the pediatric oncology ward, you come across a case of metastatic triphasic nephroblastoma in a 4-year-old. What is the most common site for metastasis of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The most common sites for metastases of nephroblastoma or Wilms tumor are the following:

  • Lungs (Most common)
  • Regional lymph nodes
  • Liver

The triphasic components visualized on histopathology are- 

  1. Malignant small round (blue) cells (blastemal component).
  2. Tubular structures/rosettes (epithelial component).
  3. Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component)

questions.text: What is the most important determinant of prognosis in a child diagnosed with Wilm's tumor?

choices.text: Loss of heterozygosity of chromosome 1 p

questions.solution:
Histology is the most important determinant of prognosis in Wilm's Tumor. The absence of anaplasia is considered a favorable histological finding.

Other prognostic factors for risk-adapted therapy include

  • Age
  • Stage
  • Tumor weight
  • Loss of heterozygosity at chromosomes 1p and 16q.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child comes with abdominal distension, a palpable mass, and gross hematuria.  A biopsy of the mass shows the following picture. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes in not associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows the characteristic triphasic components of Wilm's tumor. 

Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy is not a paraneoplastic syndrome of Wilm's tumor.

Several distinct paraneoplastic syndromes have been reported in Wilm's tumor. They are as follows:

  • Hypertension
  • Erythrocytosis/Polycythemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Cushing syndrome
  • Acquired von Willebrand disease

Bleeding may occur as a paraneoplastic syndrome in Wilm's tumor. It is due to acquired deficiency of von Willebrand factor or factor VII deficiency. 

The triphasic components visualized on histopathology are- 

  1. Malignant small round (blue) cells (blastemal component).
  2. Tubular structures/rosettes (epithelial component).
  3. Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component)

questions.text: The most common soft tissue sarcoma in the pediatric age group is______.
questions.solution:
Rhabdomyosarcoma, a tumor of striated skeletal muscle, is the most common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma.

The most common sites are- head and neck (25%) > genitourinary tract (24%) > extremities (19%) > orbit (9%).

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents with the lesion shown in this picture. The diagnosis is_____.
questions.solution:
The lesion seen in the picture is sarcoma botryoides

Vaginal rhabdomyosarcoma may manifest as a grape-like mass of tumor tissue bulging through the vaginal orifice, known as sarcoma botryoides.

questions.text: The precursor lesion of Wilm's tumor is _______.
questions.solution:
• Wilms tumor is derived from foci of incompletely differentiated/undifferentiated renal mesenchyme called nephrogenic rests.
  • Nephrogenic rests usually regress or differentiate, but those that persist can become malignant.
  • Nephrogenic rests that persist abnormally in the kidneys into postnatal life are seen in 1% of children in the general population, but are seen in up to 90% of children who develop or have a family history of Wilms tumor.

questions.text: The term â€œtrilateral retinoblastomaâ€ refers to bilateral retinoblastoma + ___________.
questions.solution:
A pineoblastoma occurring in a child with bilateral hereditary retinoblastoma is called “trilateral retinoblastoma.”

In hereditary retinoblastoma (having spontaneous germline RB1 mutation), second malignancies are a major concern. The most common second malignancy is osteosarcoma; other second neoplasms include rhabdomyosarcoma and melanoma.

questions.text: Tumor which may undergo spontaneous regression is ______.
questions.solution: Neuroblastoma is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral sympathetic nervous system with heterogeneous presentation and prognosis; some tumors may undergo spontaneous regression, whereas some may be unresponsive to therapy and run a very aggressive course.

questions.text: Which of the following pediatric tumors is called a â€œtriphasic" blastoma?
questions.solution:
• The classic nephroblastoma, aka Wilms tumor, is a mixed tumor (more than one neoplastic cell type) derived from one germ-cell layer (examples: Wilms tumor and pleomorphic adenoma of salivary gland).
  • Histologically, it is made up of the classic "triphasic" combination (recapitulating stages of normal renal development) of
    • Stromal
    • Epithelial, and
    • Blast cells
